pullrequest.title: Only initialize the marker service in the client (GUI) scene [targeting gazebo8]

content.raw:
Just curious, were the markers showing up on the server scene? (visible to camera sensors) 

I can imagine use-cases for adding markers that are visible to sensors, but I suspect this may not have been tested when markers were added.

Just curious, were the markers showing up on the server scene? (visible to camera sensors)

pullrequest.title: Only initialize the marker service in the client (GUI) scene [targeting gazebo8]

content.raw:
That's a good point.

The `MarkerVisual` sets its visibility flag to `GZ_VISIBILITY_GUI` by default. The marker message seems to contain an optional `visibility` field which can be set to `GUI` or `ALL`, but I don't see that flag getting used anywhere in `MarkerVisual.cc` or `MarkerManager.cc`, so as far as I can tell, that message flag will never have an effect. As a result, the marker will never be visible to cameras, even if it gets added to the server scene with the `visibility` flag set to `ALL`.

An alternative fix for this might be to create two marker services: `/marker/gui` and `/marker/sensors` or something along those lines. Then we can choose which type of service a scene should offer based on whether it's a server scene or a client scene. That would mean eliminating the `visibility` flag, but that flag isn't getting used anyhow.
content.html:
That's a good point.

The MarkerVisual sets its visibility flag to GZ_VISIBILITY_GUI by default. The marker message seems to contain an optional visibility field which can be set to GUI or ALL, but I don't see that flag getting used anywhere in MarkerVisual.cc or MarkerManager.cc, so as far as I can tell, that message flag will never have an effect. As a result, the marker will never be visible to cameras, even if it gets added to the server scene with the visibility flag set to ALL.

An alternative fix for this might be to create two marker services: /marker/gui and /marker/sensors or something along those lines. Then we can choose which type of service a scene should offer based on whether it's a server scene or a client scene. That would mean eliminating the visibility flag, but that flag isn't getting used anyhow.

pullrequest.title: Only initialize the marker service in the client (GUI) scene [targeting gazebo8]

content.raw:
`MarkerVisual`s  are probably only meant for the GUI. This is consistent with our other `*Visual` class that has the same `GZ_VISIBILITY_GUI` visibility flag. 

If we want to extend the ability to visualize markers on the server side, I assume we can just overwrite the `MarkerVisual`'s visibility flag based on the `visibility` field in the msg.
content.html:
MarkerVisuals are probably only meant for the GUI. This is consistent with our other *Visual class that has the same GZ_VISIBILITY_GUI visibility flag.

If we want to extend the ability to visualize markers on the server side, I assume we can just overwrite the MarkerVisual's visibility flag based on the visibility field in the msg.

pullrequest.title: Only initialize the marker service in the client (GUI) scene [targeting gazebo8]

content.raw: One thing I'm not clear on is whether a marker that gets generated in the GUI process with a visibility of `ALL` would ever get received by the server process. Is there a mechanism for syncing up the two scenes?
content.html: One thing I'm not clear on is whether a marker that gets generated in the GUI process with a visibility of ALL would ever get received by the server process. Is there a mechanism for syncing up the two scenes?

pullrequest.title: Only initialize the marker service in the client (GUI) scene [targeting gazebo8]

content.raw: oh I was imagining that the MarkerManager would be enabled on both server and client. When a message is received, MarkerVisuals are created on both sides with `GZ_VISIBILITY_GUI`. If `visibility` field is present then override the existing visibility flag [after the MarkerVisual is created](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/bcbea7608b1ad88067ef652e8e7a4b93ec1001cf/gazebo/rendering/MarkerManager.cc?fileviewer=file-view-default#MarkerManager.cc-253) (e.g. `GZ_VISIBILITY_ALL` and now the server will also be able to see the marker)
content.html: oh I was imagining that the MarkerManager would be enabled on both server and client. When a message is received, MarkerVisuals are created on both sides with GZ_VISIBILITY_GUI. If visibility field is present then override the existing visibility flag after the MarkerVisual is created (e.g. GZ_VISIBILITY_ALL and now the server will also be able to see the marker)

pullrequest.title: Only initialize the marker service in the client (GUI) scene [targeting gazebo8]

content.raw:
The issue with having a `MarkerManager` in both processes is that if a service request is emitted from a server or client process, then the other process won't ever receive the message. `ign-transport` doesn't really seem designed to gracefully handle multiple services offering the same service with the same name. I think this has gone unnoticed because we're generally requesting markers using the `gz marker` command line tool, which is always going to be running in its own process.

I think it would be good to be able to request markers from either process and reliably see them appear. I'm working on validating a sensor plugin right now, and I'd like it to be able to spawn a GUI marker at a location whenever the sensor picks up on a certain signal. Without the fix in this PR, that is currently impossible because the request gets eaten up by the `MarkerManager` in the server process and the request is never seen by the client process.
content.html:
The issue with having a MarkerManager in both processes is that if a service request is emitted from a server or client process, then the other process won't ever receive the message. ign-transport doesn't really seem designed to gracefully handle multiple services offering the same service with the same name. I think this has gone unnoticed because we're generally requesting markers using the gz marker command line tool, which is always going to be running in its own process.

I think it would be good to be able to request markers from either process and reliably see them appear. I'm working on validating a sensor plugin right now, and I'd like it to be able to spawn a GUI marker at a location whenever the sensor picks up on a certain signal. Without the fix in this PR, that is currently impossible because the request gets eaten up by the MarkerManager in the server process and the request is never seen by the client process.

pullrequest.title: Only initialize the marker service in the client (GUI) scene [targeting gazebo8]

content.raw:
I'm genuinely not sure how that's able to work, although I tested it without this PR's modification, and it definitely worked.

I'll need to investigate this more deeply in order to understand why publishing the marker message would work in a `ModelPlugin` but failed in my `SensorPlugin` until this PR's change was made.

Perhaps there's a syncing mechanism between the scenes of the two processes that I need to know more about.
content.html:
I'm genuinely not sure how that's able to work, although I tested it without this PR's modification, and it definitely worked.

I'll need to investigate this more deeply in order to understand why publishing the marker message would work in a ModelPlugin but failed in my SensorPlugin until this PR's change was made.

Perhaps there's a syncing mechanism between the scenes of the two processes that I need to know more about.

pullrequest.title: Only initialize the marker service in the client (GUI) scene [targeting gazebo8]

content.raw:
Yup, that's it. I changed `plot3d.world` like this:

~~~
diff -r 1105f45a0edf worlds/plot3d.world
--- a/worlds/plot3d.world	Wed Jan 17 16:34:16 2018 -0800
+++ b/worlds/plot3d.world	Fri Jan 19 17:31:35 2018 -0800
@@ -9,6 +9,9 @@
     <include>
       <uri>model://ground_plane</uri>
     </include>
+    <include>
+      <uri>model://camera</uri>
+    </include>
 
     <model name="plot_pendulum">
       <include>
~~~

Then opened:

`gzserver plot3d.world`

And then `gzclient`

The markers are not there.
content.html:
Yup, that's it. I changed plot3d.world like this:

diff -r 1105f45a0edf worlds/plot3d.world

+++ b/worlds/plot3d.world   Fri Jan 19 17:31:35 2018 -0800
@@ -9,6 +9,9 @@
     <include>
       <uri>model://ground_plane</uri>
     </include>
+    <include>
+      <uri>model://camera</uri>
+    </include>

       <include>

Then opened:

And then gzclient

pullrequest.title: Only initialize the marker service in the client (GUI) scene [targeting gazebo8]

content.raw:
So I'm fine with merging this into Gazebo8 so it works consistently for the client scene. It could be worth it adding a note to the example [README](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/8a59b5f0f0b9bda21ee905098b47900da492ba9c/examples/stand_alone/marker/?at=default) mentioning markers won't be visible for camera sensors.

And then we ticket an issue about splitting the service into 2, or turning it into a simple pub/sub so that multiple subscribers can subscribe to the same topic.
content.html:
So I'm fine with merging this into Gazebo8 so it works consistently for the client scene. It could be worth it adding a note to the example README mentioning markers won't be visible for camera sensors.

And then we ticket an issue about splitting the service into 2, or turning it into a simple pub/sub so that multiple subscribers can subscribe to the same topic.
